text:
hey hey, I've already dropped this question in the other community, but I want to collect as many opinions as possible :slightly_smiling_face:

The question is on *content updates.* We launched the site exactly 2 years ago and started with a very narrow topic (native advertising). We were growing slowly but steadily, expanded to overall advertising & affiliate marketing-related topics, and organic traffic started to grow faster. This February, the traffic (read: rankings) started to drop, and since I was blocked with other projects from April, we didn't have a chance to focus on the site and address the issue. Now, I'm finally able to look into it. I want to start with checking our top-performing articles & updating them. My questions are:

• How do you update content that's not entirely outdated? Do you just add more content? 
• How soon are you able to see whether the changes have helped or not?
• And probably you can share some tips on what typically works for you :raised_hands:

elements.text: hey hey, I've already dropped this question in the other community, but I want to collect as many opinions as possible
The question is on
content updates.

We launched the site exactly 2 years ago and started with a very narrow topic (native advertising). We were growing slowly but steadily, expanded to overall advertising & affiliate marketing-related topics, and organic traffic started to grow faster. This February, the traffic (read: rankings) started to drop, and since I was blocked with other projects from April, we didn't have a chance to focus on the site and address the issue. Now, I'm finally able to look into it. I want to start with checking our top-performing articles & updating them. My questions are:
How do you update content that's not entirely outdated? Do you just add more content?
How soon are you able to see whether the changes have helped or not?
And probably you can share some tips on what typically works for you

text:
How do you update content that's not entirely outdated? Do you just add more content?

Add more _revelant_ content by checking what people are also searching for on Google. Or what you think is missing yourself. Or what competitors are including.

But make sure it's _relevant._

I find asking someone outside of the niche to read the post and pose me any questions they still have after reading.

This makes my article more comprehensive, less likely to be clicked away from (and back to Google), and ensures I'm not biased.

Example: Tom Hirst wrote _the best_ <https://www.tomhirst.com/getting-started-with-nfts/|article> I've read about NFTs - but I still had questions:

• why are some NFTs free?
• why is gas so expensive?
I can't be the only one thinking these things so hopefully he adds them in so it becomes *the only article I need to read on the topic.*

text: I'm reactive because of the number of articles we have at Mio and limited resources. So if I notice a drop in traffic, ranking, or conversions then I investigate if an article needs refreshing.

elements.text: I'm reactive because of the number of articles we have at Mio and limited resources. So if I notice a drop in traffic, ranking, or conversions then I investigate if an article needs refreshing.

text:
When we optimize posts, we also use Clearscope to make sure we're meeting user intent (with secondary keywords, Google questions, etc.). 

I also agree with the advice above — looking through the top articles should give you some indication as to what value you're not offering that someone else is.

Other things to consider:

• If you get off-topic somewhat in the existing version of the article, cut that section
. Make sure what's there actually matches user intent, rather than just exists to exist.
• Make sure to use internal linking wisely
. Many people forget to link old pieces to new ones, and you'd ideally be linking articles on the same topic back and forth to each other to establish authority.
• See if there is a type of media/creative you can use to beef up the article
. Are there videos on the subject? Should you have a table that breaks down info in a certain way? Do you need screenshots?
• Check the backlink profile of your site over time
. If you lost a large portion of links in a small period of time, that may be one reason your rankings tanked. 
• Finally, make sure that you address UX issues that exist
. I've seen great content struggle to rank because a site had really bad mobile UX and users never spent enough time there to get anything from it. 

I’d expect at least a week or two to see if you're going to trend up or down. But I'd probably give it 4-6 weeks to see if your changes truly worked. 

Hope this is helpful!! :raised_hands::skin-tone-3:

elements.text: When we optimize posts, we also use Clearscope to make sure we're meeting user intent (with secondary keywords, Google questions, etc.).
I also agree with the advice above — looking through the top articles should give you some indication as to what value you're not offering that someone else is.
Other things to consider:
If you get off-topic somewhat in the existing version of the article, cut that section
. Make sure what's there actually matches user intent, rather than just exists to exist.
Make sure to use internal linking wisely
. Many people forget to link old pieces to new ones, and you'd ideally be linking articles on the same topic back and forth to each other to establish authority.
See if there is a type of media/creative you can use to beef up the article
. Are there videos on the subject? Should you have a table that breaks down info in a certain way? Do you need screenshots?
Check the backlink profile of your site over time
. If you lost a large portion of links in a small period of time, that may be one reason your rankings tanked.
Finally, make sure that you address UX issues that exist
. I've seen great content struggle to rank because a site had really bad mobile UX and users never spent enough time there to get anything from it.

I’d expect at least a week or two to see if you're going to trend up or down. But I'd probably give it 4-6 weeks to see if your changes truly worked. 

Hope this is helpful!!

text:
I've done content refreshes before that have been really successful. I think that the key is identifying WHY you're refreshing the content:

• Did your content drop in search results as a result of the keywords becoming more competitive?
• Does other top-ranking content better meet the search intent?
• Did your original post miss the mark with search intent?
The reason for the refresh - addressing one of the above - would change how I do a refresh. But in any case, I'm usually not afraid to cut entire sections or do pretty large re-writes of an existing post in hopes that it will perform better.

elements.text: I've done content refreshes before that have been really successful. I think that the key is identifying WHY you're refreshing the content:
Did your content drop in search results as a result of the keywords becoming more competitive?
Does other top-ranking content better meet the search intent?
Did your original post miss the mark with search intent?

The reason for the refresh - addressing one of the above - would change how I do a refresh. But in any case, I'm usually not afraid to cut entire sections or do pretty large re-writes of an existing post in hopes that it will perform better.

text:
If an e-commerce site has dozens of product pages that aren't optimized for SEO, what's the best optimization approach?
Start with just a few to see if the techniques work, or
Optimize them all at once?

elements.text:
If an e-commerce site has dozens of product pages that aren't optimized for SEO, what's the best optimization approach?
Start with just a few to see if the techniques work, or
Optimize them all at once?

text: I would actually start with category pages if it's an ecommerce site. But to answer your question, i would optimize them all at once with the basics - ie. keyword in title tag, h1, url etc...

elements.text: I would actually start with category pages if it's an ecommerce site. But to answer your question, i would optimize them all at once with the basics - ie. keyword in title tag, h1, url etc...

text: With SEO, there isn't really a "try a little bit and if it works, do more" approach. It's very much a zero sum game so definitely prioritize, but look at it at from a "campaign" mindset versus a tactical mindset

elements.text: With SEO, there isn't really a "try a little bit and if it works, do more" approach. It's very much a zero sum game so definitely prioritize, but look at it at from a "campaign" mindset versus a tactical mindset

text:
<@U01L6NE17PA> So, when focusing on written content, create the content for the category pages first? I'm thinking about on-page SEO predominantly.

<@UUXMCJQ15> How so?

elements.text: So, when focusing on written content, create the content for the category pages first? I'm thinking about on-page SEO predominantly.
How so?

text: Yeah I would create the content for the category pages first and then tackle the individual product pages.

elements.text: Yeah I would create the content for the category pages first and then tackle the individual product pages.

text: <@U01L6NE17PA> Would you also work on long-form blog content at the same time to boost rankings and awareness, or focus just on the product pages? This is for a smaller team with limited resources.

elements.text: Would you also work on long-form blog content at the same time to boost rankings and awareness, or focus just on the product pages? This is for a smaller team with limited resources.

text:
SEO has a lot of factors and it's a zero sum game. If I get traffic for a KW, that traffic doesn't go to the people that rank lower than me, etc.

Optimizing 4 pages on a site doesn't account for how authoritative the site is overall either in terms of topical authority or (sigh) backlinks.

Treating SEO like a campaign where we look at all the pieces is a lot more helpful than doing a few tactical things and see if they work.

In this case, do them all.

elements.text:
SEO has a lot of factors and it's a zero sum game. If I get traffic for a KW, that traffic doesn't go to the people that rank lower than me, etc.

Optimizing 4 pages on a site doesn't account for how authoritative the site is overall either in terms of topical authority or (sigh) backlinks.

Treating SEO like a campaign where we look at all the pieces is a lot more helpful than doing a few tactical things and see if they work.

In this case, do them all.

text: With limited resources, I would focus getting the category pages and product pages dialed in from an on-page SEO perspective. Then while those pages are being ranked, I would focus on creating the long-form blogs to create topical relevance, get more backlinks (referring domains) and give yourself opportunities to create internal links.

elements.text: With limited resources, I would focus getting the category pages and product pages dialed in from an on-page SEO perspective. Then while those pages are being ranked, I would focus on creating the long-form blogs to create topical relevance, get more backlinks (referring domains) and give yourself opportunities to create internal links.
